ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: At my school, there is a teacher or some other adult who really cares about me
Notes: 1=Not true at all; 2=A little true; 3=Pretty much true; 4=Very much true

ElementDescription: At my school, there is a teacher or some other adult who tells me when I do a good job
Notes: 1=Not true at all; 2=A little true; 3=Pretty much true; 4=Very much true

ElementDescription: At my school, there is a teacher or some other adult who notices when I am not there
Notes: 1=Not true at all; 2=A little true; 3=Pretty much true; 4=Very much true

ElementDescription: At my school, there is a teacher or some other adult who wants me to do my best
Notes: 1=Not true at all; 2=A little true; 3=Pretty much true; 4=Very much true

ElementDescription: At my school, there is a teacher or some other adult who listens to me when I have something to say
Notes: 1=Not true at all; 2=A little true; 3=Pretty much true; 4=Very much true

ElementDescription: At my school, there is a teacher or some other adult who believes I will be a success
Notes: 1=Not true at all; 2=A little true; 3=Pretty much true; 4=Very much true

ElementDescription: I do interesting things at school
Notes: 1=Not true at all; 2=A little true; 3=Pretty much true; 4=Very much true

ElementDescription: At school I help decide things like class activities or rules
Notes: 1=Not true at all; 2=A little true; 3=Pretty much true; 4=Very much true

ElementDescription: At school I do things that make a difference
Notes: 1=Not true at all; 2=A little true; 3=Pretty much true; 4=Very much true

ElementDescription: School Climate - Mean Score
Notes: Average of items sclimate_1 through sclimate_9

ElementDescription: School Climate - Sum Score
Notes: Sum of items sclimate_1 through sclimate_9

ElementDescription: I feel close to people at my school
I am happy to be at this school
I feel like I am part of this school
The teachers at my school treat students fairly
I feel safe in my school
School Connectedness - Mean Score
Notes: Average of items sconnect_1 through sconnect_5

ElementDescription: School Connectedness - Sum Score
Notes: Sum of items sconnect_1 through sconnect_5

ElementDescription: When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do your teachers, coaches, and staff... Notice that it is happening?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do your teachers, coaches, and staff... Try to stop it?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do your teachers, coaches, and staff... Ignore it?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do your teachers, coaches, and staff... Talk openly about it?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do your teachers, coaches, and staff... Listen to both sides of the story?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do your teachers, coaches, and staff... Make fair decisions?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do your teachers, coaches, and staff... Have consequences for the person who is being mean?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do your teachers, coaches, and staff... Support the person who has been hurt or targeted?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do your teachers, coaches, and staff... Understand the situation?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do your teachers, coaches, and staff... Join in and contribute to the mean and hurtful things being done?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do other students... Notice that it is happening?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do other students... Try to stop it?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do other students... Ignore it?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do other students... Talk openly about it?
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do other students... Support the person who has been hurt or targeted?

When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do other students... Have consequences for the person who is being mean? (e.g., turning them in, or telling an adult)
When students are doing mean and hurtful things to one another at school, how often do other students... Join in and contribute to the mean and hurtful things being said or done?

Does your school have a student-led club that aims to create a safe, welcome, and accepting school environments for all youth, regardless of sexual orientation or gender identity? These clubs are sometimes called gender and sexuality alliances (GSA).
How often do you participate in GSA meetings and/or activities?

Does your school identify ''safe spaces'' (e.g., a counselor's office, designated classroom, or student organization) where LGBTQ+ youth can receive support from administrators, teachers, or other school staff?
Does your school prohibit harassment based on a student's perceived or actual sexual orientation or gender identity?
Does your school encourage staff to attend professional development on safe and supportive school environments for all students, regardless of sexual orientation or gender identity?
Does your school provide access to mental or physical health care services that specialize in care for LGBTQ+ youth, and are not on school property?

Does your school provide curricula or supplementary materials that include HIV, STD, or pregnancy prevention information that is relevant to LGBTQ+ youth (e.g., curricula or materials that use inclusive language or terminology?)
